question: Why are annual recommendations for influenza vaccine composition necessary? Why is the flu vaccine needed every year?
answer: There are 2 reasons why the flu vaccine is needed every year: (1) a person’s immunity wanes over time so a shot is needed for maximal protection (2) the flu virus constantly undergoes structural changes, that’s why vaccines are updated based on research on which strains will be common.

question: What are the WHO recommendations for influenza vaccination? What influenza strains should I be protected from?
answer:
This year, as recommended by WHO, the content of vaccine for 2022 influenza season (southern hemisphere) are the following:
  • Egg-based vaccines:
    • an A/Victoria/2570/2019 (H1N1)pdm09-like virus;
    • an A/Darwin/9/2021 (H3N2)-like virus;
    • a B/Austria/1359417/2021 (B/Victoria lineage)-like virus; and
    • a B/Phuket/3073/2013 (B/Yamagata lineage)-like virus.
    • Cell- or recombinant-based vaccines:
    • an A/Wisconsin/588/2019 (H1N1)pdm09-like virus;
    • an A/Darwin/6/2021 (H3N2)-like virus;
    • a B/Austria/1359417/2021 (B/Victoria lineage)-like virus; and
    • a B/Phuket/3073/2013 (B/Yamagata lineage)-like virus.

question: How effective is the vaccine?
answer: Influenza vaccination is 40-60% effective in preventing the complications brought about by Influenza or the “flu” such as pneumonia.

question: How long does the vaccination last?
answer: The protection lasts for one year. Re-immunization should be done annually.

question: How long after vaccination does it take for the antibodies against the “flu” to be produced?
answer: It takes up to two (2) weeks after vaccination for antibodies that protect against flu to develop in the body.

question: Who should NOT receive the vaccine?
answer:
• Children who are younger than 6 mos of age
  • Individuals who experienced severe, life threatening allergic reactions to any ingredient of a flu vaccine (Might include gelatin, antibiotics, or other ingredients)
  • Individuals who previously manifested a severe allergic reaction to a dose of influenza vaccine and might not be able to receive other flu vaccines

question: What are the possible side effects of the vaccine?
answer: The most common side effect is soreness at the injection site. Some of the less common side effects are pain, low-grade fever, myalgia, headache, and fatigue.

question: Can you get influenza from the vaccine?
answer: You cannot get the flu from being vaccinated with the flu vaccine. The vaccines administered are composed of either inactivated (killed) viruses, or with a single protein component of the influenza virus.
